title: 105_hr2985
content: Aliens are ineligible for visas and excluded from admission for nonpayment of child support. Aliens can be deemed inadmissible for failing to pay child support exceeding $5,000 as per the Immigration and Nationality Act. Aliens can be deemed inadmissible for failing to pay child support exceeding $5,000. The amendment made by this section applies to visas issued on or after 180 days after the enactment of this Act. Aliens can be deemed inadmissible for failing to pay child support exceeding $5,000. The amendment applies to visas issued on or after 180 days after the enactment of this Act. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include deporting aliens who fail to pay child support exceeding $5,000. This amendment will take effect 180 days after the enactment of the Act. Aliens legally obligated to pay child support must satisfy payments before being eligible for naturalization. The amendment applies to naturalization applications filed 180 days after the Act's enactment. Additionally, legal process serving in child support cases on certain arriving aliens is authorized. Immigration officers can serve legal process on alien applicants for child support enforcement, as authorized by an amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act. The amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act allows immigration officers to serve legal process on alien applicants for child support enforcement. This amendment applies to aliens applying for admission to the United States 180 days after the enactment of the Act. The Social Security Act is amended to allow the Immigration and Naturalization Service to request information on delinquent child support payments from the Secretary.
